node.title: $40m of public money for private law firms
node.description: Why do we give $41 million each year to private law firms to conduct public prosecutions? Guyon Espiner investigates.

node.title: Not a single Māori Crown prosecutor in Chch, Gisborne, Whanganui
node.description: Many of the private law firms with warrants to prosecute serious crimes are failing to reflect the diversity of the regions they serve - even though it's a condition of their contracts.

node.title: Kiwis in need of legal aid stung by interest that outstrips mortgage rates
node.description: Some of New Zealand's poorest citizens now owe a share of $177 million in legal debt - and the government's charging them 5 percent interest.

node.title: Man horrified 92 ACC staff accessed his sensitive claim file
node.description: A man disabled by a workplace accident is horrified dozens of ACC staff looked at his sensitive claim file on childhood sexual abuse, viewing it more than 350 times after it was closed. Anusha Bradley…

node.title: Legal aid system 'broken and may collapse' - Chief Justice
node.description: Hourly rates for legal aid lawyers haven't increased since 2008 and there are now almost no lawyers prepared to do civil legal aid work in some parts of the country.

node.title: Minimum wage earners, pensioners no longer qualify for legal aid
node.description: The number of New Zealanders eligible for legal aid has plummeted from an estimated 1.2 million in 2007 to 400,000.

node.title: Covid-19 data visualisations: NZ in numbers
node.description: How has Auckland's move to alert level 3 step 1 impacted the Covid-19 outbreak? Track the latest case numbers, testing and vaccination data in New Zealand.

node.title: ACC staff posted clients' details to Snapchat group
node.description: ACC call centre workers shared details of people's injuries and mocked them on Snapchat, RNZ can reveal.

node.title: Kiwifruit growers take council to High Court over land valuation method
node.description: Kiwifruit growers are taking Gisborne District Council to the High Court for including the licence to grow the gold variety in rating land valuations.

node.title: Sunflower seed study unlocks a new market in Canterbury
node.description: Canterbury farmers looking for an additional crop to add to the mix this summer might do well to look at sowing sunflower seeds.

node.title: Anchor Food Professionals reaches $3bn in annual revenue
node.description: Anchor Food Professionals - Fonterra's foodservice business - has defied Covid challenges to become a $3 billion annual revenue business.

node.title: Avocado prices tumble: 'Everyone's going to run at a loss this year'
node.description: New Zealand Avocado chief executive Jen Scoular says this will be one of the toughest seasons the industry has had in the last decade.

node.title: T&G Global lowers full year profit expectations
node.description: Persistent labour shortages and rising shipping costs has forced produce grower and exporter T&G Global to lower its full-year profit expectations.

node.title: 'Time for them to go': Call for ban on colony farming
node.description: SAFE has written an open letter calling on the Agriculture Minister to ban colony cages, which it says has the backing of hundreds of New Zealand veterinary professionals.

node.title: Changes to dairy product names likely needed for EU trade deal - minister
node.description: Trade Minister Damien O'Connor is back from a two-week trip to the US and EU and says good progress has been made on trade talks.

node.title: 10 percent of Central Otago-grown fruit going to waste, report finds
node.description: A new report has found the region's unharvested fruit loss was estimated at 8.6 percent, while harvested fruit that was not sold amounted to 4.2 percent.

node.title: Meat industry backs mandatory vaccination for sector workers
node.description: The meat processing industry says it would support a vaccine mandate for staff.

node.title: Nine-cent avocados: Glut leads to low prices - but it's not so flash for growers
node.description: A glut of avocados this year has led in extraordinarily low prices at the supermarket, despite growers not being able to make any money.

node.title: Dropping tarrifs won't necessarily make British gin cheaper here
node.description: The Free Trade Agreement struck between the UK and New Zealand is expected to benefit gin and whisky exporters on both sides, although it's unclear whether consumers here will notice any change in…

node.title: Canterbury ANZCO feedlot faces inspection
node.description: The Ministry for Primary Industries says it will carry out an inspection on a Canterbury beef feedlot, after an animal welfare complaint was received.

node.title: Tomato exports to eight countries still off the table due to plant disease
node.description: The contagious plant disease Pepino Mosaic Virus was found in April putting exports to eight countries are on hold as growers head into the peak season.

node.title: Entrepreneurial farmers use own wool to make blankets and yarns
node.description: Country Life: At The Grampians in North Canterbury, a couple are using the fleece from their hoggets to produce merino blankets and knitting yarn. Audio

node.title: On the Farm - a wrap of farming conditions around NZ
node.description: Country Life: Hawke's Bay had a 29 degree day this week and a bit of rain. That makes it a risky time for fire-blight in apples. Spring sowing of next year's winter feed paddocks is in full swing in…

node.title: Zespri cuts the volume of gold kiwifruit licences on offer next March
node.description: Gold kiwifruit growers have had outstanding returns in recent years, on average receiving nearly $178,000 per hectare last season, but a handbrake is being put on future development.

node.title: Govt funding to speed up medicinal cannabis industry
node.description: The government is putting $760,000 into a joint research programme to speed up the establishment of a medicinal cannabis industry here.

node.title: Surfing for Farmers kicks off for another summer
node.description: This year the initiative is being run at 21 different beaches around the country, with six new locations coming onboard and hopes of up to a thousand individual farmers taking part.

node.title: Wilding pine control efforts praised for efforts exceeding expectations
node.description: Biosecurity Minister Damien O'Connor said the programme had made huge strides in it's first year - tackling more than half of its four-year target.

node.title: Jimmy Kimmel: Biden Is Steady but Slow, Like ‘Grandpa at the Wheel’
node.description: “He’ll get us there, it’ll just happen very slowly with the blinker on the whole ride,” Kimmel joked of the president and his 38 percent approval rating.

node.title: Growing regulation causing added stress for dairy farmers - Survey
node.description: A new industry survey has found many dairy farmers are feeling under pressure, despite strong prices.

node.title: Farmers urged to create Covid-19 checklist
node.description: Farmers are being urged to create a check list on how to run their farm in case they get Covid-19 and can't do so themselves.

node.title: 'Revolution in nutrition': Fonterra hopes to boost health benefits of dairy products
node.description: Fonterra has announced a deal for the design of dairy products that incorporate targeted release of specific nutrients.

node.title: Some farmers out of step with more stringent winter grazing rules - report
node.description: Regional councils are taking winter grazing more seriously but there are still some farms not demonstrating good practice, a new report has found.

node.title: KiwiSaver third quarter returns relatively unaffected by lockdowns
node.description: KiwiSaver funds reflected subdued market conditions over the September quarter, with the bulk experiencing a return of less than one percent.

node.title: Westpac commits $300m to sustainable investments
node.description: The investment arm of Westpac Bank NZ is committing up to $300m to sustainable investments that adhere to strict global standards.

node.title: Xero offers free counselling to business owners: 'It's an incredibly tough time'
node.description: Xero is offering free counselling sessions to more than 200,000 small business owners in Auckland over the strain of more than 80 days lockdown.

node.title: Trustpower reports solid profit gain on higher electricity generation
node.description: Trustpower's first half profit increased as it produced more power at higher prices, and gained from a rise in the value of its electricity hedges.

node.title: Auckland farmers' markets wait for traffic light system before reopening
node.description: Two of Auckland's most popular farmers' markets will not be reopening next week, though they would be allowed to under level 3 step2.

node.title: Kiwibank owner calls time on life insurance business
node.description: The owner of Kiwibank has become the latest financial services provider to sell off its insurance business.

node.title: Government tells telecoms to hang up misleading marketing
node.description: The telecommunications sector has been told to clean up its marketing and selling tactics as the old copper line phone network and exchanges are dismantled.

node.title: $1.3m boost for study of erosion, sediment control measures in forestry sector
node.description: A seven-year forestry study aims to determine the most effective measures for reducing erosion and sediment in rivers from harvesting.

node.title: Auckland Covid-19 restrictions easing still leaves some businesses out in the cold
node.description: Some businesses are welcoming the news while others still unable to open aren't impressed with the rules under alert level 3 step 2. Audio

node.title: Air NZ to require vaccination or negative Covid-19 test for domestic flights
node.description: All passengers on Air New Zealand domestic flights will need to be fully vaccinated or have a negative Covid-19 test from mid-December. Audio

node.title: Deep-tech investment fund becomes first listing on Catalist capital market
node.description: A technology investment company will be the first listing on Catalist - the recently established capital market for small and medium-sized businesses.

node.title: First home buyers 'very active' in housing market
node.description: First home buyers' share of the property market has reached a record high, but it remains to be seen if the momentum can be sustained.

node.title: Armstrong's car dealers considering NZX and ASX listing
node.description: One of the country's biggest car dealers, Armstrong's, is considering listing on the New Zealand and Australian stock exchanges.

node.title: NZ company's toothpaste sales surge in partnership with Chinese influencer
node.description: A New Zealand oral care company is all smiles after a partnership with a Chinese influencer saw its sales go through the roof ahead of the Singles' Day holiday.

node.title: Pitch invader denies Welsh shot at win over world champions
node.description: A pitch invader has cost Wales a chance at beating South Africa in Cardiff.

node.title: Two five-wicket hauls for Kerr in Wellington wins
node.description: White Ferns all-rounder Melie Kerr has backed up yesterday's five-wicket bag for Wellington with a second today as the Blaze recorded back-to-back one-day wins over Canterbury in Rangiora.

node.title: Ko lights up in third round blitz, Alker one shot off lead
node.description: Lydia Ko has stormed into a four-shot lead after a firing a course record in the third round of the Ladies European Tour event in Saudi Arabia.

node.title: Wary of Afghan spin threat, New Zealand back their own strengths
node.description: New Zealand are aware of the threat posed by Afghanistan's spin attack, but the Black Caps are confident of sealing a semi-final spot in the Twenty20 World Cup with a win in Abu Dhabi, leg-spinner Ish…

node.title: Black Caps into semi-finals at T20 World Cup
node.description: New Zealand crushed a billion Indian dreams and breezed into the semi-finals of the Twenty20 World Cup with an eight-wicket victory against Afghanistan.

node.title: Ko wins in Saudi Arabia
node.description: New Zealand golfer Lydia Ko fired a final round of 65 to triumph by five shots at the Saudi Ladies International in Jeddah.

node.title: Verstappen wins in Mexico to extend F1 championship lead
node.description: Red Bull's Max Verstappen celebrated a dominant win in the Mexico City Grand Prix to surge 19 points clear of Lewis Hamilton in the Formula One championship with four races remaining.

node.title: Black Ferns still have a lot of homework to do
node.description: They may have hammered the Black Ferns again, but England aren't prepared to take the favourites tag for next year's Rugby World Cup.

node.title: Great day for New Zealand golfers
node.description: It's been a memorable day for New Zealand golfers around the world.

node.title: Scotland's Russell to take Lions lessons into Springbok test
node.description: Scotland first-five Finn Russell believes they can claim their second big scalp in a week when they host South Africa at Murrayfield this weekend.

node.title: England will be formidable opponents for Black Caps
node.description: England will be formidable T20 World Cup opponents even in the absence of injured opener Jason Roy, New Zealand bowler Adam Milne said.

node.title: New Yorkshire cricket chairman apologies to Rafiq, promises change
node.description: New Yorkshire Cricket Club chairman Kamlesh Patel has apologised to former player Azeem Rafiq over the county's handling of his racism allegations.

node.title: Jackie Stewart will pay tribute at Fangio memorial
node.description: Triple world champion Jackie Stewart will pay tribute to Formula One great Manuel Fangio this week when the Argentine's last remains are moved to a new resting place.

node.title: Major Asia-Pacific trade deal ratified
node.description: New Zealand has ratified a major free-trade agreement involving China, Japan, South Korea and 10 other South-East countries.

node.title: National petitions to end MIQ for vaccinated travellers
node.description: The National Party has launched a petition to end what it calls "state-sponsored human cruelty" for travellers required to go through managed isolation.

node.title: Deputy PM on time slots for Christmas travel: 'It wouldn't be very practical'
node.description: Aucklanders will probably have a better option than allocated time to leave the region over the holidays, the deputy prime minister says. Audio

node.title: NZ-affiliated Afghans unfairly denied visas, court told
node.description: Lawyers acting for Afghans unable to get visas to come here have told the High Court the government has not acted fairly.

node.title: Covid-19 briefing: More than $5b paid out during Delta outbreak
node.description: The government says more than $5 billion has been paid out in economic support since the Delta outbreak began in August. Watch the government's latest update here.

node.title: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern postpones Europe trip
node.description: Plans for a possible trip to support free trade negotiations in Europe later this month had been under consideration.

node.title: More freedom, more Covid - worries about easing Auckland's restrictions
node.description: Week in Politics - The government decides to ease Auckland's restrictions, raises Covid-19 concerns, while anti-vaxxers start creating problems and DHBs strive to reach the 90 per cent target.

node.title: Labour Party to vote on proposal to change system of electing new leader
node.description: The Labour Party is holding its first conference since its landslide win in the 2020 election.

node.title: $25k event proposed to spur Invercargill City Council participation
node.description: The proposal follows comments from a community panel that more needed to be done to encourage a more diverse and representative council.

node.title: 'The fair thing to do' - Govt to increase payments to struggling families
node.description: Almost 350,000 families will get an extra $20 a week from April next year, lifting 6000 more children out of poverty, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern says.

node.title: Focus on Politics: Will traffic lights see Covid hitting the gas?
node.description: Podcast - "If we don't all rush back out to try and get back to that level 1 life then the system will work better". This week, we put on the brakes and look at what the traffic light system means for… Audio

node.title: Living wage guaranteed to public service contractors
node.description: Cleaners, caterers, security guards and other contractors for core public service departments and agencies will be paid at least the living wage of $22.75 an hour, the government says.

node.title: Eight killed after crowd surge at US music festival
node.description: At least eight people have died and scores of people have been hurt after a crowd surge on the opening night of a music festival in Houston, Texas.

node.title: Dire Straits member John Illsley: 'We weren't part of a trend and never have been'
node.description: As punk music took hold, Dire Straits enjoyed huge success with a style of rock all their own which found favour worldwide including in Aotearoa, founding member John Illsley says. Audio

node.title: Scores dead after tanker explosion in Sierra Leone
node.description: The accident happened after the tanker collided with another vehicle in the nation's capital, Freetown.

node.title: 'Long overdue': Biden hails passing of infrastructure bill as monumental step
node.description: The long-delayed $US1 trillion spending package is a major domestic win for the president.

node.title: 'Feminist perspective' promised as author begins new Bond trilogy
node.description: Author Kim Sherwood is to write a new trilogy of James Bond books, becoming the first female author in the series of spy novels created by Ian Fleming.

node.title: Well-preserved ancient slave room unearthed in Pompeii
node.description: Archaeologists have discovered a room of objects among the buried remains of ancient Pompeii, and say its contents shed light on the lives of slaves.

node.title: Criminal probe opened into stampede at rap concert that left 8 dead
node.description: A criminal investigation has been opened after a stampede during rap star Travis Scott's Astroworld music festival in Houston killed at least eight people

node.title: Prince Charles to visit Barbados to mark republic's birth
node.description: Prince Charles will travel to Barbados to mark the Caribbean island's transition to a republic which entails the removal of Queen Elizabeth as head of state.

node.title: No sign of shark attack victim as search continues
node.description: There is still no sign of a man believed to have been taken by a shark at Port Beach in Western Australia on Saturday morning.

node.title: Sydney to further ease Covid-19 curbs as vaccinations pick up
node.description: Sydney will further ease social distancing curbs tomorrow, a month after emerging from a coronavirus lockdown that lasted nearly 100 days, as close to 90 percent of people have got both doses of…

node.title: Attempted assassination against Iraq's prime minister fails
node.description: An explosive-laden drone has targeted the Iraqi prime minister's residence in what the country's military say was an unsuccessful assassination attempt.

node.title: Founding member of band UB40 dies at 64
node.description: British vocalist and founding member of UB40 Terence Wilson, better known by his stage name Astro, has died aged 64. Video

node.title: Northern Ireland row puts UK-EU trade deal under threat
node.description: Former UK Prime Minister Sir John Major warns suspending parts of the Northern Ireland Protocol Brexit deal would be a "colossally stupid" move.

node.title: Rittenhouse said he 'had to shoot' after opening fire, jury hears
node.description: Shortly after opening fire during racial justice protests in Wisconsin in 2020, teenager Kyle Rittenhouse told a witness in his murder trial that he had no choice but to use his semi-automatic rifle…

node.title: Hamilton train to run to central Auckland when service resumes
node.description: The Hamilton to Auckland commuter train will travel direct into central Auckland once the service resumes.

node.title: AstraZeneca vaccine will soon be available for some - Bloomfield
node.description: The Director-General of Health says for the "few hundred people" in NZ who could not have the Pfizer vaccine "for medical reasons" there was the option of AstraZeneca.

node.title: Company director jailed for sharing child sex abuse material
node.description: A Hamilton man has been jailed for sharing child sexual abuse material online.

node.title: Covid-19: 147 new community cases today, another death in home isolation
node.description: There have been 147 new cases of Covid-19 reported in the community today - including 14 in Waikato - with another death of someone with Covid-19 who was isolating at home.

node.title: DOC to stop waiving concession fees for tourism operators
node.description: Tourism leaders are warning businesses may fold after the Department of Conservation announced it will stop waiving concession fees.

node.title: Person with Covid visited Taranaki at start of November, DHB believes
node.description: Recent wastewater results suggest a Covid-infectious person was in Taranaki from the start of November, the region's top doctor says.

node.title: School reeling after three staff die in crash
node.description: The principal of a New Plymouth school which has lost three staff members in a horror crash in Horowhenua says the community is reeling at the news.

node.title: School's (almost) back: 'Anything we can do to get them back there safely is fine with us'
node.description: It's been three months since most Auckland students have been in the classroom, one parent says learning from home hasn't been easy for anyone.

node.title: Two men, one woman arrested over West Auckland murder
node.description: Three people have been arrested and charged with murder for the killing of Robert Hart in the Auckland suburb of New Lynn last week.

node.title: Democrats’ Divide: Should Obama-Era Economic Ideas Prevail in 2021?
node.description: A more traditional view is competing against a newer approach that has become mainstream among economists.

node.title: C.D.C. Recommends Covid Booster Shots for Millions of Americans
node.description: Recipients of the Moderna and the J.&J. vaccines may receive extra doses. The agency also embraced a “mix-and-match” strategy.

node.title: Men Are Caregivers, Too, in Democrats’ Plan
node.description: Compared with its peers, the U.S. has little in the way of family policy, but where it exists, it has mostly treated men and women the same. The Democrats’ plan would cement that.

node.title: Proposed Tax on Billionaires Raises Question: What’s Income?
node.description: Democrats are homing in on unrealized capital gains raises as a way to help fund their social spending bill.

node.title: This May Be Democrats’ Best Chance to Lower Drug Prices
node.description: For patients with certain cancers, out-of-pocket spending can exceed $15,000 a year. Legislation could take aim at prices and the amounts Medicare patients are charged.

node.title: In the Biden Bill, the Billionaires Beat the Working Rich
node.description: One by one, tax proposals that would have slowed dynastic wealth have been tossed from the agreement.
